hero.title: Trump Accounts, Explained in Plain English
hero.subtitle: Your child may qualify for a $1,000 federal investment account. We translate IRS jargon into simple answers for exhausted parents, confused employers, and overwhelmed tax preparers.
qualify.title: Who Qualifies for a Trump Account?
qualify.subtitle: There are only three requirements — and no income limit.
qualify.citizenDesc: The child must be a United States citizen
qualify.ssnDesc: Must have a Social Security Number
qualify.ageDesc: Must be under 18 at end of election year
qualify.pilotNote: $1,000 federal pilot deposit: Only children born January 1, 2025 – December 31, 2028 receive the free $1,000. Children born outside this window can still open a Trump Account — they just won't get the deposit. There are no income restrictions — a family earning $30K and a family earning $3M both qualify equally.
calcs.title: Try Our Free Calculators
calcs.subtitle: All tools run in your browser. We don't collect or store any personal data.
hubs.title: Everything You Need to Know
hubs.whatDesc: The complete guide to IRC §530A — eligibility, contributions, investments, and what happens at age 18.
hubs.howTitle: How to Open a Trump Account
hubs.howDesc: Step-by-step guide to IRS Form 4547, the trumpaccounts.gov portal, and filing with your 2025 tax return.
hubs.irsDesc: We translate the IRS's guidance document into language a tired parent can understand at 11pm.
hubs.compareTitle: Trump Account vs 529 vs Roth IRA
hubs.compareDesc: Side-by-side comparison of every children's savings option. Limits, tax treatment, flexibility.
hubs.employerDesc: How to set up a Trump Account contribution program. $2,500/yr per employee, tax-free.
hubs.faqDesc: Eligibility, taxes, divorce, disability, FAFSA, market crashes, and every edge case.
translation.title: The Translation Layer
translation.subtitle: We read the IRS documents so you don't have to.
translation.plainText: It's an investment account opened for your kid. The money belongs to them. It's held by a financial institution (like Fidelity or Vanguard) and invested in S&P 500 index funds until they turn 18.
faqPreview.title: Frequently Asked Questions
